text: Reason is, and ought only to be the slave of the passions, and can never pretend to any other office than to serve and obey them.
author: David Hume

text: It is not reason, which carries the prize, but experience.
author: David Hume

text: The life of man is of no greater importance to the universe than that of an oyster.
author: David Hume

text: Truth springs from argument amongst friends.
author: David Hume

text: A wise man proportions his belief to the evidence.
author: David Hume

text: Probability is the very guide to life.
author: David Hume

text: Custom, then, is the great guide of human life.
author: David Hume

text: The mind is a kind of theatre, where several perceptions successively make their appearance; pass, repass, glide away, and mingle in an infinite variety of postures and situations.
author: David Hume

text: Beauty in things exists merely in the mind which contemplates them.
author: David Hume

text: Where reason fails us, we are not able to establish any conclusion concerning the relation of cause and effect.
author: David Hume
